bibl.title: Letter from Francisco Dominguez Roldan to Philip Showalter Hench, September 10, 1940

div1.p: Dominguez Roldan describes his book on Finlay's yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Francisco Dominguez Roldan to Philip Showalter Hench, September 10, 1940
div1.opener:
Dominguez
MENDOZA Y GUTIERREZ
MARIANAO
HABANA
Habana, September I0. I940
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic.
Rocherster. Minn.
3/6/41 - sent Roch P. B,
& Mile Port
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I have received your letter of August I4th and appreciate very
much your desire to have more details about my book; I beg you to ex-
cuse me for not having answered you any sooner.

My book has been translated into English and Spanish, I have the
prices and conditions from an American firm, but the wordly situation
has prevented it from beeing printed as I so much wished.

Finlay's discovery haw been almost unbeleived for twenty years, on-
ly a few French and German men of science had known the value of it, a
and when the American Military Board came to Havana with Dr. Reed
all the most trascendent problems concerning yellow fever had been
solved; for instance, the mosquito had been chosen out as the only
transmitter, the works proofs of the transmission had been done, the
mosquito's life studied, the female pointed out as the only one to tra-
nsmit the disease, the works on vaccination and serotherapy done, etc.,
you will find all these details in my book.

But the most important fact is the study made by Dr. Finlay on the
mild forms of the disease, from which he made his statistics; these
statistics have not been accepted by the American Board because they
had not presented any clasical type of yellow fever.

Actually, all the data presented by Finlay have been scientifically
confirmed and, nowadays, in medical science, we must admit that yellow
fever in its most frequent endemical form, was a mild and inapparent
Dr Philip S. Hench...
MENDOZA Y GUTIERREZ
MARIANAO
HABANA
type able to inmunize the patiente suffering from the attack.

That is why the natives of the places where the yellow fever was en-
demical were exempted because they had suffered the disease in their
childhood. The other type, serious, sometimes mortal which occured chiefly
during the season of greatest heat because then the virulence of the
mosquito was greater, can be considered as a mere accident within the
endemical state.

Experience has taught us the importance of Finlay's works, and I who
have lived with him can affirm that he was a genius.

Dr. Carroll who had been bitten by a mosquito sought for the parasite
of paludism in his blood; Dr. Lazear who had made experiments without
results, allowed an infected mosquito bite him at the hospital in spite
of the warning of his companions, and paid his inexperience with his life
however, he knew the value of the mosquito for he had worked with Dr.
Grassy in Italy before coming to Cuba.

Meanwhile, Dr. Reed was in Washington finishing his work on typhoid
fever which he had started as a member of the Whitmann Board. Therefore
it is a mistake to beleive that Dr. Reed was the author of the disco-
very.

The first experimental case of inocculation by the mosquito was made
by Drs Lazear and Agramonte upon the soldier Dean, and it proved right
the theory of Finlay. General Leonard Wood, Governor General of Cuba and
himself a surgeon, informed his government of it. You will find all this
in the first pages of my book.
I should like to hear from your works .and remain, dear Dr. Hench.

closer.seg:
P.S.- Under separate cover I am mailing you a copy of the “Anales de la Academia de
Ciencias, etc”. On page 301 there appears a lecture by Dr. Branly on Finlay's works.
